etymology.description: semantic: 亻(人) (rén, "person") + phonetic: 孜(孜) (zī) -> trained warrior; from practice of identifying experienced warriors as being 'ripe' or seasoned
etymology.interpretation: The character 孰(孰) (shú, "cooked; ripe") combines the semantic element 亻(亻) (rén, "person") to indicate skill or experience, and uses 孜(孜) (zī) as the phonetic component, reflecting the idea of something or someone being seasoned or matured, analogous to being 'cooked' or 'ripe.'

examples.chinese: 鸡肉已孰(雞肉已孰)，可以食用(可以食用)。
examples.english: The chicken is cooked; it can be eaten.

examples.chinese: 瓜果已孰(瓜果已孰)，味道香甜(味道香甜)。
examples.english: The fruits are ripe; their flavor is sweet.

examples.chinese: 待食材孰熟(待食材孰熟)，大厨方展技艺(大廚方展技藝)。
examples.pinyin: Dài shícái shú shú, dà chú fāng zhǎn jì yì.
examples.english: When the ingredients are cooked, the chef can showcase his skills.
